comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: There's vast numbers of boaters being worn. Was that the style of the day or is there some boater related event on (Provost's garden party or something)?

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: An electric tram and a horse-drawn tram should help with the dating.  I believe electrification started in 1896 and was complete by 1901.  But when did the last horse trams stop?

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content:
I spy at least two top hats.
One on a gent just passing the Trinity front gate, and another on a man about to leave frame on left.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: There's a bicycle in the modern (post 1890) style on the left in front of the Bank of Ireland. It's a bit blurred but it has two wheels the same size, a trapezoid frame and a chain driven rear wheel.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Dublin Trams: This was completed in four years and when the last horse tram ran on the Bath Avenue line in January 1901, the Dublin area had about 66 electric route miles, of which nearly 50 were owned by the DUTC.

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: I digress but ..... The DUTC opened its first bus route in 1925, progressively replacing the trams until the closure of their last route, the No. 8 to Dalkey, on 10 July 1949. According to then Minister for Justice Seán Mac Eoin "A force of 60 guards, including 2 superintendents, 1 inspector, 8 sergeants and 3 motor-cyclists were placed on duty over the route." were unable to protect the last tram from damage by souvenir hunters.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Does that spherical streetlamp provide any dating evidence?

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: So, it's between 16 May 1896 (date of first electric tram) and Jan 1901 (date of last horse tram).

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Thanks all! Changing to 1900 for the moment then...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Off down Westmoreland Street, is that the Irish Times clock? I can't find a firm date for it, but I find some references saying it dates from the early 1900s, and that the Irish Times moved to Westmoreland Street in 1895.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Just checked edition of Irish Times for Thursday, 3 January 1895 and they were in Westmoreland Street then. Bottom right of back page says: "Printed and Published by James Carlyle, of 8 Belvedere place, in the City of Dublin, for the Proprietor at the Office, 31 Westmoreland street, in the Parish of St. Marks, City of Dublin" Still checking - in Westmoreland Street in January 1884... Think they moved from Abbey Street in 1882/83-ish
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: To the archives! This Lawrence photo shows no electric wires, but it has the clock, so the clock is no help after all, as it was there before the wires.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Ah, "rhymes with mugger" - good thinking anyway...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] The Post box isn't there now but could have been VR 1837-1901 or EVIIR 1901-1910 . If it was EVIIR comined with the horse drawn tram it would nail it to 1901 but as we can't see it I guess we'll have to keep looking.

PS Got my Georges and Edwards mixed on the note.

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/shanekillen] According to Ask About Ireland, the last horse tram ran on 13 Jan 1901. (Edward VII didn't come to the throne until 22 Jan 1901), There is a horse tram in the photo, so it is definitely before 13 Jan 1901.

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward/] Good enough for me.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Here is a good article about Dublin Street Lighting, showing that the ornate electric lamps date from 1892. They were powered from a new station at Fleet St. 1903-1910 - "Sometime during this period these relatively young electric lampposts were removed, probably due their antiquated technology. It's possible it happened in 1903 as this is the year the Fleet St station shut down in favour of the Pigeon House. "

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: The men all seem to have Bowler hats; Wikipedia says they were "popular with the working class during the Victorian era" (which is 1837-1901). So 1900-1901 seems to fit (excuse the pun). Some of the ladies have those straw hats I associate with the barbershop quartet, don't know what the official name for them is. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:BarbershopQuartet_Disneyworld.jpg has a nice picture of the hats. Again, popular between 1900-1919...

comment.author: 22575440@N07
comment._content: this is awesome! I am sure we have all walked in front of the college hundreds of times!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Thanks again to everyone for dating work on this one. The record on our catalogue for this one, originally said 1865-1914 - a fairly broad date range, I think you'll agree. I just changed it to 1896-1901, a hell of a lot more useful! (Updates will happen tonight)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
